text: We'll hear argument next in Number 74, Original, the State of Georgia v. the State of South Carolina.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
What color is it?
They are all beige.
They are all beige.
Appendix B to Georgia's exceptions and brief [inaudible].
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

Mr. McCutchen, suppose I owned a piece of private land out in the country somewhere, and I had never even camped out on it in 50 years, and you... you had gone under dark of night and camped there a couple of nights, but I never knew about it.
No, Your Honor--
Doesn't there have to be a notoriety?
--Your Honor, there is no trouble there, because the owners were Savannah people living in Savannah, who owned the land and went to South Carolina to obtain the grant.
Well, do you... do you say it is enough to bring home the claim of the occupation to Georgia citizens, or does it have to be brought home in some way to the government of Georgia?
Well, it was brought home to everybody who was around, including the aldermen, to the city council.
And you think the Special Master was absolutely correct?
Absolutely correct.
In all phases.
With respect to Barnwell, we are supporting it.
There was a bridge over the river at this point?
--Pardon me, Your Honor?
There was a bridge over the river at this point?
No, sir, but the ferry that came from Savannah lands right by the Barnwell Islands.
What about the Fifth Circuit case in 1955?
South Carolina was not a party to that case, and there is nothing in the record to show that South Carolina knew anything about that until that case was decided.
Would Georgia's actions in that case be a prescriptive act of its own?
--Well, even if it were considered that way, that is 1955.
Mr. McCutchen, why did it take so long for this case to get here?
Well, Your Honor, we bifurcated the trial, and the case did start in 1977, and filed the reports, and, Your Honor, I could not go beyond that in saying that it has been a lengthy matter.
Is Rabbit the one right next to the two described as Barnwell Islands?
Yes, Your Honor.
Thank you, Your Honor.
But South Carolina had been on the scene all along, because that's been where the deeds were recorded and the taxes were paid, and this land was being obviously used.
--Deeds were recorded and taxes were paid in South Carolina, but those are primarily passive acts by the clerk of court.
I don't think so.
--If it was in--
